desc:
# Overview

User types “#label” in a comment of the desired file in Crowdin, followed by all the URLs of the articles to label, separated by spaces or new lines. Currently works for PT and LSS.

To set up a webhook for this purpose, navigate to the Tools tab in the desired Crowdin project, and click on Webhooks. Set trigger to “String/comment issue created.” URL is `https://labels.langops-ca.com`, method `POST`. No authentication code needs to be passed in the headers.

# Further Reading

See the readme and source code on GitHub:

[https://github.com/ddisanto-langops/automate-labels](https://github.com/ddisanto-langops/automate-labels "smartCard-inline")
name: On-Demand Labelling of .idml Files in Crowdin

desc:
Note: For questions, or to submit an updated style guide for your language, contact the maintainer: [dadisanto@pcog.org](mailto:dadisanto@pcog.org "‌")

# **What is on-demand QA?**

This is a Blackbird-based automation which performs custom quality assurance checks on approved translations. Final editors can type `#QA` in the comments section of any file containing approved translations. The approved translations (and not any others) will then be reviewed by AI against the style rules of the relevant language. Violations of the style guide will trigger comments to be posted to the relevant string with a status of unresolved translation error.

When the automated process completes, a notification will appear in the `langops-batchnotifications` channel on Slack. The relevant language manager should then inform the final editor (whose name will be displayed in the notification) that the comments are ready for review.

To see the comments, sort all the strings of the file by comments or by unresolved issues. The final editor should then check each comment, fixing any errors and marking the comment as resolved.

**Warning:** **AI makes mistakes. It’s there to aid review, not replace your knowledge of your language’s rules.**

# How do I enable it?

Note: follow these steps for all projects where you want the feature to be available.

1. Click on the `Tools` tab in the desired project
2. Click on `Add Webhook` and name it `langops-QA`
3. Under `Trigger events`, delete any pre-filled values and select only `String comment/issue created`
4. In the `URL` field, enter this URL: `https://de-1.blackbird.io/api-rest/WorkflowInstances/callback/22c88d7b-36b6-407f-990d-64e505631db9`
5. Verify `Request Method` is set to `POST` and `Content Type` is `application/json`
6. Under `Headers`, type `Authorization` in the first box, and `02460u2852gwb6` in the second box.
7. Ensure `Batch Webhooks` is left unchecked
8. Click on `Add` to save the webhook

‌

# For devs/maintainers

To edit a style guide:
name: On-Demand QA in Crowdin

desc:
[Last updated 2025-08-15]

This describes two Crowdin-optimized workflows for translation of any document.

1. **Synchronus:** for when intermediate revisions need to be archived;
2. **Asynchronus:** for when only MT and TTA versions are archived.

**Workflow 1: Synchronus translation**

1. Upload file to TMS **without** pre-translation (translated strings must initially be empty for this to work)
2. Either one of:
   1. Linguists in MTPE or PR+Q/A roles are all assigned a section and start translating (make sure auto-approve is turned **off** for everyone);
   2. The document is assigned to one linguist who is responsible for translating all of it.
3. Download revision 1 once the article is fully translated but not yet approved
4. Proceed to final edits, approval and revision download

**Workflow 2: Asynchronus translation**

1. Upload article to TMS **without** pre-translation (translated strings must initially be empty for this to work)
2. Either one of:
   1. Linguists in MTPE or PR+Q/A roles are all assigned a section and start translating (make sure auto-approve is turned **off** for everyone).
   2. One linguist in MTPE or PR+Q/A role translates entire document
3. The final editor begins revisions, starting with strings where translations have already been suggested by a linguist. The **advanced filter** can be used (select “Not Approved”). Final editor also has the authority to approve any string, whether or not other linguists have worked on it.
4. If desired, an AI-powered QA check can be performed when final edits are completed, and any issues can be resolved by the final editor.
name: Crowdin-Optimized Translation Workflows

desc:
Maintainer: [dadisanto@pcog.org](mailto:dadisanto@pcog.org "‌")

Access here: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TcIdDijmOLyMfkMVj7p5hiSHudDsW8VmgPzQ-diY8wA/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TcIdDijmOLyMfkMVj7p5hiSHudDsW8VmgPzQ-diY8wA/edit?usp=sharing "smartCard-inline")

# Overview

This spreadsheet imports feeds into named ranges and displays them in a table with selectable dates and sources. The keywords are automatically updated when feeds refresh, via an API call to OpenAI in Google Apps Script.

# How it works

The News Classification bird flies every 5 minutes. For each news source, it will:

- Loop over the associated columns using a library and check for a '1'
  - A formula in the sheet evaluates the newest article date against the last time the keywords were generated (date inserted by BB). When article date > keywords date, the forumla returns ‘1', otherwise '0’.
- Write “Updating…” in the keyword range if the value of '1' is found

When the Spreadsheet detects this change in a named range, it passes the titles and quips for the given range to OpenAI and returns the appropriate keywords.

# Editing the Sheet

Please be aware that any changes made to a named range will trigger an API call to OpenAI. To edit the sheet, click on Extensions > Apps Script > News Classification and select the triggers tab from the menu on the left. Delete the triggers and refresh the sheet. You may now make edits. **Note: When done editing, you must re-create the** `onOpen` **trigger, otherwise keywords will not update automatically. Configure it as follows:**

![image.png](https://trello.com/1/cards/67c07be3d3e9d130356e4159/attachments/67c5c1c3569505b3e1fd02f8/download/image.png)

When this trigger exists, it calls the function `setupOnChangeTrigger()` each time the sheet is opened; the sheet is then ready to listen for changes to the named range (e.g. when Blackbird inserts “Updating…”).

## How to add a news source

**Warning:** any column shifts (creating new columns before the end of the sheet) risk rendering the sheet unuseable until all columns are updated in the [Blackbird library "RSS News Ranges"](https://de-1.blackbird.io/libraries/2028 "‌"). Avoid this by only adding sources to the very end of the “Raw data” sheet.

‌

1. Delete the triggers as explained above.
2. Set up the `IMPORTFEED()` formula with the appropriate URL, limiting it to 100 lines.
3. Use helper columns with formulas to clean the data. You must transform the date string returned by the feed into a valid datetime value. Ideally, the quip should also be clean and free from line breaks.
4. The final result must include four columns: title, quip, source, and date (which must be calculated from a helper cell in the form of `DATEVALUE()+TIMEVALUE()`.
5. Add an empty fith column for keywords. It can be helpful to leave a narrow buffer column after it and before the next source, for ease of navigation.
6. Create a named range from those five columns and add it to the `FILTER()` formulas in each sheet where you want it to appear. Also add it to the dropdown list by adding the named range to the formula in column G (hidden).
7. Above the quip column (the final, cleaned quip used in the named range), set up the date checking formula. Get the `MAX()` (or latest date) of all the articles. This will be compared to the date when keywords were last updated, which Blackbird will insert in row 1 above the keywords column. The final formula should look like this: `=IF(OV1<=PB1,0,1)`. In this example, OV1 is the `MAX()` of all article dates, and PB1 is the cell above the keywords where Blackbird will insert a date.
8. Re-create the `onOpen` trigger as described in the preceding section.

# Authorisations

The necessary authorisations for Google to call a third-party API are found in Appscript.JSON under oauthScopes. If missing or invalid, an error will occur when trying to contact OpenAI and receive keywords. The permissions are as follows:

![image.png](https://trello.com/1/cards/67c07be3d3e9d130356e4159/attachments/67c07f07137363c1d0e4875b/download/image.png)
name: RSS News Spreadsheet

desc:
Filename conventions for documents in the Localization Department.

**MAGAZINES**
_Philadelphia Trumpet | Royal Vision | Let the Stones Speak_

Example:

![Screenshot\_2024-05-13\_at\_17.27.40.png](https://trello.com/1/cards/664289e68ee69358a15a112f/attachments/664294061c4f3e10222d89dc/download/Screenshot_2024-05-13_at_17.27.40.png)

Order:

The order below is preferred, but the other makes no difference.

The filename for magazine products is determined by:

- PRODUCT: Magazine issue
  Example: PT202405
- CMS ID: From [http://theTrumpet.com](http://theTrumpet.com "‌") (OPTIONAL)
  Example: 29307
- TITLE-AUTHOR-WORDCOUNT: As provided by the Publishing Dept. plus the author initials and the word count.
  Example: The Global War on Free Speech-RP2750
- SOURCE LANGUAGE-TARGET LANGUAGE
  Example: EN-ES
- VERSION: Append to the previous version
  MT, MTPE, use PR for PR + QA, TTA

---

---

**Helpful Resources:**

name: Blackbird: Filename Conventions

desc:
**REQUIRED:**

PRODUCT and EDITION:

- Always at the beginning of the filename. Followed by an underscore.
- Product + Edition: ^([A-Z])([0-9])(?=_)
- Product (Specify Group 1): ^([A-Z-]\*)([0-9]\*[A-Z]*)(?=_)
- Edition (Specify Group 2): ^([A-Z-]\*)([0-9]\*[A-Z]*)(?=_)
- Examples: [https://regex101.com/r/APuL2V/1](https://regex101.com/r/APuL2V/1 "smartCard-inline")
- Usage in Blackbird: [https://de-1.blackbird.io/birds/3085](https://de-1.blackbird.io/birds/3085 "smartCard-inline")

TITLE:

- Preceded by an underscore
- Has spaces or dashes between words
- Followed by a dash, author initials and word count
- Regex (will change based on whether it has spaces or dashes between words): (?<=_)([A-Za-z’'0-9 -]){4,}(?=-)

AUTHOR:

- Preceded by a dash
- Composed of initials (JH; RP+JM)
- followed by the word count (no symbol in between)
- Regex: (?<=-)([A-Z+]{1,})(?=\d+)

WORD COUNT:

- Preceded by the author (no symbol in between)
- Followed by an underscore
- Regex: (?<=-)(?:[A-Z+]*)([0-9]{1,})(?=_)

SOURCE-TARGET LANGUAGE:

- Preceded by an underscore
- Composed by two letter codes (EN-ES; EN-FR)
- Followed by an underscore
- Regex: (?<=_)([AENSFINLRDTOPH]{2})(?:[-])([AENSFINLRDTOPH]{2})(?![A-Za-z-])
- Group 1: Source
- Group 2: Target

**OPTIONAL:**

CMS ID:

- Preceded by an underscore
- 5-digit code
- Followed by an underscore
- Regex: (?<=_)[0-9]{5}

TIMESTAMP:

- Preceded by an underscore
- TS (Timestamp)
- Regex: (?<=_)(TS)(?![A-Za-z])

TRANSLATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:

- Preceded by an underscore
- TMS (Translation management system)
- Regex: (?<=_)(TMS)(?![A-Za-z])

‌

‌

Examples:

BCC\_Lesson24-Message From the Editor-GF500\_EN-ES
CWL\_231109-Jerusalem-GF2800\_EN-ES
KOD\_24-25-The Total Solar Eclipse and Your Potential-GF3600\_EN-ES
MB\_May 16-STAFF2000\_EN-FR
PT202405\_29307\_The Global War on Free Speech-RP+JM2750\_EN-DE\_TMS
PTVID\_WorldWatch20240517-STAFF300\_EN-PT_NTMS
SER\_2024-05-11-always-keep-growing-JH0000\_EN-ES\_NTS\_NTMS
SER\_2024-05-11-always-keep-growing-JH0000\_EN-ES\_TS\_TMS

‌

‌

[https://jex.im/regulex/#!flags=&re=%5E(a%7Cb)*%3F%24](https://jex.im/regulex/#!flags=&re=%5E(a%7Cb)*%3F%24 "smartCard-inline")
name: Blackbird: Regex for Filenames

desc:
**SYNTAX**

GENERAL:

- One task per checklist item.
  - For example:
    - `[-]@magdarodriguez emails @oliverheyer5 @marylabao CC: @adielgranados & -> [LaTrompeta.es]`
  - And not:
    - `[-]@magdarodriguez edits file and emails @oliverheyer5 @marylabao CC: @adielgranados & -> [LaTrompeta.es]`

**MOVE CARD:**

**Checklist Name:**

- ADMINISTRATION:
  - Add to the _end_ of the checklist item: `& -> [listname]`
  - The card will be move to the list “listname” when the item is checked.
- TRANSLATION:
  - Add to the _end_ of the checklist item: `& -> [listname]`
  - The card will be move to the list “listname_[language code from Custom Fields]” when the item is checked.
- PRODUCTION
  - Add to the _end_ of the checklist item: `& -> [listname]`
  - The card will be move to the list “listname” when the item is checked.

**ADD/REMOVE MEMBER:**

**Checklist item:**

- Add a member by including them after the word `emails` (max of 3 mentions and they must be separated by spaces).
- Remove a member by including `[-]` before the `@mention`. Together it looks like this: `[-]@adielgranados`(notice that there is no space in between).
- For example when the checklist item below is checked:
  `[-]@magdarodriguez emails @oliverheyer5 @marylabao CC: @adielgranados & -> [LaTrompeta.es]`
  - It removes @magdarodriguez from the card.
  - It adds @oliverheyer5 and @marylabao to the card.
  - It moves the card to the “[laTrompeta.es](http://laTrompeta.es "‌") ” list.

‌

**MAGAZINES**

1. Create magazine card
2. Create individual cards from the magazine card
   1. Add “[magazine code] [card name]” under DEPENDENCIES for each card.
      For example: “PT PT202409\_A Revolutionary Form of Government-JH1694\_EN-ES“
   2. Wait until all the cards are created.
   3. Check that everything was created correctly.
name: Trello: AUTOMATION SYNTAX

You can see it here: [https://www.canva.com/design/DAF8AKbT03Q/M0HCSz6c3vDZ4DcyFjLcHQ/edit?utm_content=DAF8AKbT03Q&utm_campaign=designshare&utm_medium=link2&utm_source=sharebutton](https://www.canva.com/design/DAF8AKbT03Q/M0HCSz6c3vDZ4DcyFjLcHQ/edit?utm_content=DAF8AKbT03Q&utm_campaign=designshare&utm_medium=link2&utm_source=sharebutton "smartCard-inline")

Just let me know if you have any ideas or thoughts about it. George and I have already discovered and made some changes (for marketing) as we were making this.

desc:
**What to look for:** After an audio file has been generated, listen through for parts where the language model has “hallucinated” and deviated significantly from the intended accent/pronunciation.

**Important notes:**

- Do the replacements **from end of audio to beginning**, otherwise your labels will be time-shifted with each edit, making it harder to identify the area needing replacement.
- Aim to generate audio **only once** for each error, unless the quality is not acceptable. Each time you click “generate,” you are using up credits.

**Procedure:**

- In Audacity, press ctrl+B to make a label track
- As you listen through, label each section needing replacement with a number.
- Open the Eleven Labs speech synthesis page in a new tab (you can have this and the project page open simultaneously)
- Copy and paste the text for the affected area, ensuring you are using the intended voice and settings
- Generate and download the new audio file, numbering it to correspond to the area being replaced
- In Audacity, press ctrl+shift+I to import the new audio and splice it into your file
- **Ensure you verify your new audio and trim out hallucinations.**
name: Eleven Labs Audio Editing

desc:
```visualbasic
Sub CountTrackChanges()
'defining variable types
Dim lInsertsWords As Long
Dim lInsertsChar As Long
Dim lDeletesWords As Long
Dim lDeletesChar As Long
Dim sTemp As String

' oRevision is an object of class Revision (corresponds to a revision in the document)
Dim oRevision As Revision

'set variables to 0
lInsertsWords = 0
lInsertsChar = 0
lDeletesWords = 0
lDeletesChar = 0

'for each revision object in the document (e.g. a tracked change)
For Each oRevision In ActiveDocument.Revisions
    Select Case oRevision.Type
    'in the case that a revision was inserted:
    Case wdRevisionInsert
    lInsertsChar = lInsertsChar + Len(oRevision.Range.Text) ' we add the length (number of characters to lInsertsChar)
    lInsertsWords = lInsertsWords + oRevision.Range.Words.Count ' we add the number of words to lInsertsWords
    Case wdRevisionDelete
    lDeletesChar = lDeletesChar + Len(oRevision.Range.Text) ' same as above for characters, but in the case of a deletion
    lDeletesWords = lDeletesWords + oRevision.Range.Words.Count ' same as above for letters, but in the case of a deletion
    End Select
Next oRevision ' proceed to next revision

' generate the message the user sees
sTemp = "Insertions" & vbCrLf
sTemp = sTemp & " Words: " & lInsertsWords & vbCrLf
sTemp = sTemp & " Characters: " & lInsertsChar & vbCrLf
sTemp = sTemp & "Deletions" & vbCrLf
sTemp = sTemp & " Words: " & lDeletesWords & vbCrLf
sTemp = sTemp & " Characters: " & lDeletesChar & vbCrLf
MsgBox sTemp
End Sub
```

desc:
Hello Production Assistants!

Whenever a new English Trumpet print goes to press, one of you will be tasked with creating a list of suggestions for which articles to cut for the Spanish, French, and German counterparts. An English Trumpet is 40 pages long, while the ES, FR, and DE are both only 32 pages. That means not every article will be included in the translated magazine.

Before any work on the magazine is done, the translation managers need to know which articles to assign to the translators. This is a bit more complicated than just cutting 8 pages worth of material. ES, FR, and DE translations are always longer than their English counterparts, meaning additional pages need to be cut to account for overflow.

**Here are tips on how to create the article assignments for PTs:**

– Start with going through the English PT and compiling a list of all of the articles, as well as how many pages each takes up. Be sure to account for the cover, TOC, and backpage as each taking up a page as well.

– Double-check that you counted all of the pages properly by using a calculator and ensuring that your list adds up to 40.

– We _always_ cut the KOD Television log (2 pages) and the WorldWatch (3 pages). That is 5 pages automatically cut. So you’ll need to get rid of roughly 6 more pages worth.

– When cutting articles, always allow for at _least_ 3 pages of overflow text. I’ve found that any less than that and it is a real struggle to make everything fit. You’ll have to end up cutting out lots of pictures, ads, captions, etc without at least 3 pages.

– This is now the difficult part, where you have to decide which articles to cut. We _always_ keep the cover, TOC, Cover page article/first article, the Infographic, backpage, and anything written by Mr. Gerald Flurry, so those are automatically safe. Good ones to cut usually are the commentaries and principles of living articles (unless they are by Mr Flurry, which they occasionally are).

```
Some factors to consider are things such as:
     – Pray about it first (you are the one responsible here for choosing what articles are seen/read. It is important not to cut anything that God would really want them to see. We really want Him to be the one making the decision on what to include and what to cut.)
     – Who wrote the article (Ex. it would be preferable to keep an article by Mr Hilliker as opposed to one by a non-minister.)
     – The audience (if you have to choose between cutting an article about Europe, especially ones involving Germany or France, versus an article in the Middle East/Asia/South America etc, it is usually better to keep the ones on Europe for the FR and DE publications considering the target audience/languages it is being translated into. But the reverse might be true of the Spanish PTs – might be better to keep articles pertaining to South America versus Europe if you have to choose between the two. Have to use judgment here.)
     – Insets (sometimes, it might be better to cut several insets embedded within the articles, rather than cutting the larger articles.)
```

– As seen in the attached image, you can indicate which articles you are cutting by changing the font to red and using strikethrough.

– After cutting articles, use a calculator again to ensure that your remaining articles add up to your desired page count. Ideally, this would be 29 pages + 3 pages for overflow text, but that may vary by a third of a page or thereabouts.

– Send article suggestion list to Production Managers (@:515b4f537473b93e7200252f @victorgranados6 ) and to Language Managers (@:6078386266beb879e0657312 @emmanuelmichels ).

– If the Language Managers accept your suggestions, they will send out the assignments for each article to all of the translators. You then will receive the articles from the language manager as they are translated/edited, at which point, you can begin putting them into the InDesign file.

---

If you like puzzles, doing the article assignments is a really fun part of being a Production Assistant. It’s a really important part of layout and quite special to be trusted with it. Don’t get down if you make some mistakes in the beginning. It can be a bit challenging at first. But after the first try or two, you’ll totally get the hang of it! I hope you enjoy this part of the job as much as I did. You’ve got this! =)

Warm Regards,
Selah Harms
name: How to Create Article Assignments for PTs

desc: Above the Fold Ads need to be created for _Trumpet_ magazines after completing layout. Here are the steps for that process.

desc:
Every week, the KOD is translated into German, French, and Spanish. Each of these languages requires translating the thumbnail, to be displayed on their respective Trumpet websites and YouTube channels. Three types of each of these need to be made weekly: a 5MB, 2MB, and “player” version. You may also need to create the Dutch thumbnail, which is the same as the English thumbnail but with a player bar beneath it.

**BEFORE GETTING STARTED:**

- Create a folder on your desktop called "FLT KOD Thumbnails."
- Download and save the two files attached to this Trello card entitled "\_\_KOD thumbnail template.psd" and "Key Of David\_FLT\_French\_Logo\_Template.ai" to your new folder.

NOTE: Creating KOD Thumbnails requires access to the Publishing folder.

NOTE: These instructions use the keyboard shortcuts on a Mac. For Windows shortcuts, you will need to lookup the corresponding keys.
name: How to Create KOD Thumbnails

Translations Department > Translations Archive > Administration > Contact Information Templates

desc:
Angled covers are the three-dimensional images advertising a certain publication. These angled covers are often used at the end of articles in Trumpet magazines and at the back of books and booklets to point readers to related literature.

When doing the layout for a publication, we have to recreate these covers in the target language. Below are instructions for how to do that.
name: How to Make Angled Covers in Photoshop for Ads

desc:
After a magazine is approved, you will need to do two things with the infographic:

1. Export it as a spread/jpg in a high resolution. Easy!
2. Follow the steps in the attached video to create an infographic image.

Then, email to @etrebels , @victorgranados6 , and @marylabao .

**NOTE:** If you are working on a _Trumpet_, you will need to rearrange the magazine so that the infographic falls directly on pages 14-15, the middle spread where the staples lie (in English, the middle spread is pages 17-18 because the publication is 40 pages but since German, French, and Spanish only have 32 pages, the infographic needs to be on pages 14-15. This does not matter for infographics in LSS because we do not get them professionally printed in those languages).
name: How to Make an Infographic and Infographic Image

The purpose and goal of the _Trumpet_ Waiting Room Subscription Program is to:

Sincerely, 
Deepika M. Azariah	 
Print Liaison Philadelphia Church of God | 14400-A S Bryant | Edmond, OK 73034 Tel: 405-340-7474 | Fax: 405-359-6280 dazariah@pcog.org
 
Begin forwarded message:

From: Joel Hilliker <joelh@pcog.org>
Subject: Re: Date consistency in a booklet
Date: July 26, 2021 at 11:01:43 AM CDT
To: Ryan Malone <rmalone@pcog.org>
Cc: Deepika Azariah <dazariah@pcog.org>

Thank you, eagle eyes!
 
On Jul 26, 2021, at 11:00 AM, Ryan Malone <rmalone@pcog.org> wrote:

Hi there,

I’ve been using the 721-718 b.c. date of Israel’s Assyrian captivity as a fixed/benchmark date for all Old Testament chronology — when appropriate to do so. The date is so firm because of the 2,520-year-prophecy as spelled out in USBIP. Most Bible chronologists won’t look at it that way, but we do. That’s why I made an edit to that effect in the Treason in America booklet when discussing Jeroboam II’s dates. 

At any rate, I noticed that in the KEY OF DAVID book, a date was given for the 6-year reign of Athaliah in Judah — who started reigning the same year the Jehu began reigning in Israel, because Jehu killed her son Ahaziah. 

Booklet says: 
This is the story of Joash’s coronation. At that time there was a great civil war in Israel. Athaliah was an evil queen who had usurped her authority by slaying all the princes. She ruled from 843 to 837 b.c. …

I think it’s pretty straightforward chronology, working back from the Assyrian captivity that Athaliah’s rule started closer to 860 b.c. Of course, the date is not the significant issue in the sentence (rather that Josh was crowned by the pillar stone), so I wouldn’t suggest trading one specific date for another. I might suggest replacing that last sentence quote above with: “She ruled for six years in the mid-9th-century B.C.” That leaves it a little looser and doesn’t change any of the intent of the paragraph.

RM

desc:
Opi ymmärtämään Raamattua!

Ilmoittaudu ilmaiselle Herbert W. Armstrong College -raamattukirjekurssille.

Saattaa kuulostaa uskomattomalta, mutta Raamattu kirjattiin meidän päiviämme – juuri nykyistä sukupolvea varten! Mikään toinen kirja ei ole yhtä ajan tasalla kuin Raamattu. Raamattu selittää syyt nykyiseen maailmantilaan ja paljastaa, mitä lähivuosina tapahtuu. Sen sivuilta löydät ratkaisut jokaiseen kohtaamasi ongelmaan – henkilökohtaisiin, perhesuhde-, kansantalouden ja ulkopolitiikan ongelmiin.

On ironista, että tämä hämmästyttävä teos on teoksista vähiten ymmärretty. Valtaosa myöntää Raamattua lukiessaan, ettei yksinkertaisesti ymmärrä sen sanomaa. Moni olettaa, että sanoma on nykyihmiselle epäolennainen ja vanhentunut.

Raamattua on mahdollista oppia ymmärtämään!

Herbert W. Armstrong College on auttanut raamattukirjekurssin kautta tuhansia ymmärtämään nykyisiä maailmantapahtumia sekä elämän tosi tarkoitusta. Yli 100 000 opiskelijaa eri puolilla maailmaa on ilmoittautunut tälle ainutlaatuiselle, 36 oppituntia käsittävälle Raamatun sanomaa ymmärtämään pyrkivälle kirjekurssille.
Kurssi on maksuton, eikä velvoita yhteenottoon.

Kurssi opastaa tutkimaan Raamattua systemaattisesti. Raamattu on kurssin ainoa oppikirja.

Kun rekisteröidyt verkossa, saat automaattisesti neljä ensimmäistä oppituntia sekä niihin liittyvän testin, minkä suoritettuasi saat seuraavat neljä oppituntia, toistuen aina kurssin loppuun saakka. Jos haluat oppitunnit postitse, ota yhteyttä ja tilaa postikurssi, sekin maksutta.

Ala opiskella Raamattuasi!
 
Vieraile verkossa, kirjoita lähimpään alueosoitteeseemme tai soita, ja ilmoittaudu Herbert W. Armstrong College -raamattukirjekurssille.

desc:
# Edits:

Adjunto el texto con la(s) observcion(es). La observación es con la palabra "Uplift" or "Uplifting", estaba traducida como "elevar". Favor encuentre en amarillo las correcciones. 

Elevar, se usa mas para cosas físicas, como por ejemplo "elevar un globo".

Uplifting, tiene varios sinónimos o significados que se pueden usar en español, según el contexto. Por Ej. Motivar estimular, edificar, animar, alentar, motivar...etc.

Yo puse la palabra que me pareció mas adecuada.

(A lo mejor esas explicaciones sobran...)

También aproveché y corregí un error de ortografía: Elije (debe ser con "g": Elige. Esta resaltado en amarillo).

Igualmente, en el ultimo párrafo, cambié: "verla"  por "...ve a Jerusalén". Pienso que le da un mejor énfasis y no deja la frase tan abstracta para el lector. Utilicé  directamente el sujeto al que se refiere: Jerusalén.

‌

Puede ser que ya alguien haya notado estos detalles, pero por si de pronto, es mejor que sobren y que no falten.

desc: Eliakim is a father “to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.” Jerusalem is a type of Israel and Judah. Looking at this spiritually, it is talking about the Church of God (spiritual Israel) and the very elect—the spiritual Jews of Revelation 3:9. He is also the father of “the house of Judah”—not the inhabitants of Judah. That means Eliakim is the father of a work in Judah. This Eliakim type has a key that unlocks an astounding work in the Jewish state in the Middle East. He will be doing an inspiring work in that land.
